sub_title: Assistant Professor at UMC Utrecht, Julius Center
summary:
I am an expert in discovering, testing, and applying novel study designs and analysis methods for patient-oriented clinical research, notably to direct individualized treatment and care decision-making. Since 2016, my research has increasingly focused on individualized clinical decision-making in cancer treatment, with a strong emphasis on risk prediction models. 

I am the national senior methodologist responsible for the development, validation, updating and implementation of clinical models that predict treatment effectiveness and radiation-induced toxicity to guide radiotherapy strategies, e.g., proton therapy. In this internationally renowned and unique project, I collaborate closely with (inter)national stakeholders, e.g., PMC, EORTC, NVRO, Zorginstituut Nederland, Zorgverzekeraars Nederland, and NFK. This work directly impacts clinical practice in The Netherlands and beyond as it is directly applied in the clinical prediction models that are currently nationally and internationally used for model-based treatment decisions.

I currently lead a team of researchers on personalized prediction model-based treatment decisions in cancer patients, especially in radiotherapy. Since 2016, after my 2-year visit to Stanford University (personal NWO Rubicon grant; supervisor: Prof. John Ioannidis), I have gradually and successfully expanded my team via multiple successful grant applications, e.g., ZonMw, Horizon 2020, KWF. I am also the vice chair of the Methods of Epidemiological Research Team at the Julius Center. My broad training, combining clinical epidemiology with biomedical engineering, allows me to effectively collaborate and connect team projects with ongoing initiatives. 

Additionally, I am an expert in the development and application of novel methods to evaluate healthcare innovations. These innovations are notably medical devices, meaning I have MDR and IVDR expertise: I performed 5 landmark COVID-19 rapid antigen testing studies and evaluated >30 commercial healthcare innovations at THINC. Since recently, I hold a senior advisor position for the nationwide network of Zorgevaluatie & Gepast Gebruik (ZE&GG).

My work has been published in high-impact journals (140 papers; cited >8000 times) and incorporated in clinical guidelines. I contributed to >20 successful grant applications (>20M euros).

Future plans
My team and I will focus on developing and applying cutting-edge techniques in epidemiology, statistics, precision medicine (molecular diagnostics), and data science (e.g., AI) to further optimize clinical decision-making in cancer.

authors.headline: Assistant Professor at UMC Utrecht, Julius Center

profile_positions.location: Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care, UMC Utrecht
profile_positions.description:
At the Julius Center I am part of the Methodology Program (head: Prof.dr. Karel G.M. Moons), specifically the Epidemiology Methods group. My work includes both empirical studies aimed at enhancing personalized management as well as developing methods for prediction research and individual participant data meta-analysis, specifically for subgroup analysis. I am and have been involved several large international individual participant data meta-analyses in which I combine all available data from clinical studies on the effectiveness of a certain treatment to prevent a certain disease. Within these meta-analyses I also focus on subgroup effects to investigate whether certain individuals may benefit more from treatment than others (e.g. males vs. females).
Additionally, I have reviewed, developed and validated numerous clinical prediction models that aim to predict the future occurrence of a disease based on clinical characteristics of individual patients. 
From Sept 2014 till Aug 2016 I was a visiting assistant professor at the Julius Center as I was appointed as a postdoctoral research fellow at Stanford University (see below)
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: I serve as the methodologist (focus on study design and statistical analysis) in the Medical Ethics Review Committee (METC) / Institutional Review Board (IRB) at the UMC Utrecht
profile_positions.title: Committee Member 'Medical Ethics Review Committee'

profile_positions.description: The Ureka Mega Challenge is an internal competition at the UMC Utrecht between care professionals that have a novel idea to improve healthcare. During this 8 month incubator style challenge the innovators will be preselected based on their initial idea, will advance to pitch their idea, will write a business plan, and eventually after a grand finale with multiple presentations one innovator will receive a grant prize of €50.000,=. Together with a team of knowledge people I am involved in all the steps leading to the final selection of the winner, including the initial critical appraisal of the healthcare innovations, pre-selection of these innovations to advance to the pitch round, and eventually the business case. Additionally, all team member are appointed to one or more of the innovators to guide them through the challenge and provide them with valuable advice.
profile_positions.title: Team Member 'Ureka Mega Challenge'

profile_positions.location: Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care
profile_positions.description:
In November 2009 I started my doctoral study at the Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care, University Medical Center Utrecht, Utrecht, The Netherlands (Prof. K.G.M. Moons), in collaboration with the Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Academic Medical Centre, Amsterdam, the Netherlands (Prof. B.W.J. Mol). My thesis was titled "Risk-based management in obstetrics" and involved applied research, and partly methodological research on improved methods for clinical research, notably prognostic, diagnostic, and therapeutic research. Further, my research included both primary research as well as meta-analytical research. On 25 March 2013 I successfully defended my thesis which contained 10 scientific papers in only 3,5 years.
During my doctoral studies I conducted and managed two individual patient data meta-analyses in which I collaborated with investigators from over 20 countries.
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate

profile_positions.description:
At Vanderbilt University I teach epidemiology in the Master of Science in Clinical Investigation (MSCI). 

The course provides an introduction to the principles of the design and analyses of evidence based clinical studies.  The course will cover the concept of causation versus prediction, the design of (clinical) epidemiological research, measures of disease frequency and association, validity issues including confounding, and the generalizability of research to practice.  Subsequently, the course addresses in more detail the design and analysis of diagnostic, prognostic, therapeutic and etiologic (side effects) research.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: At the Department of Radiotherapy I work as a methodological consultant with a specific focus on prediction research
profile_positions.title: Visiting Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: I assist in performing systematic reviews and meta-analyses
profile_positions.title: Affiliated Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Editorial Board Member for BioMed Central's Diagnostic and Prognostic Research journal.

"Diagnostic and Prognostic Research encompasses diagnostic and prognostic research addressing studies on the evaluation of medical tests, markers, prediction models, decision tools and apps. Diagnostic and Prognostic Research provides a platform for disseminating empirical primary studies, systematic reviews (including meta-analyses) as well as articles on methodology, protocols and commentaries addressing diagnostic and prognostic studies. The journal ensures that the results of all well-conducted diagnostic and prognostic research are published, regardless of their outcome."
profile_positions.title: Editorial Board Member 'Diagnostic and Prognostic Research

profile_positions.description:
Associate Editor for BioMed Central's Pregnancy & Childbirth journal.

"BMC Pregnancy & Childbirth is an open access, peer-reviewed journal that considers articles on all aspects of pregnancy and childbirth. The journal welcomes submissions on the biomedical aspects of pregnancy, breastfeeding, labor, maternal health, maternity care, trends and sociological aspects of pregnancy and childbirth."
profile_positions.title: Associate Editor 'BMC Pregnancy & Childbirth'

profile_positions.description: The Healthcare Innovation Center (THINC.), part of the UMC Utrecht, offers short-cycle tailor-made research of innovations in healthcare. With a multidisciplinary team of enthusiastic professionals, we evaluate your innovation regarding cost-effectiveness, usability, and feasibility. We also provide expert methodological advice. All this to build a convincing portfolio for your innovation. From idea to implementation, we help developers of healthcare innovations move forward. For more information, visit www.thinc.healthcare
profile_positions.title: Methodologist

profile_positions.description:
I’ve been working at Stanford University at the Stanford Prevention Research Center (SPRC; http://prevention.stanford.edu/) and the Meta-Research Innovation Center at Stanford (METRICS; metrics.stanford.edu) under supervision of Prof. Ioannidis for the last 2 years (NWO Rubicon Grant). I focus on methodology for the use and application of individual participant data (IPD) of treatment effects in network meta-analysis, a evidence synthesis technique that allows simultaneous comparison of several treatments that are available to cure a certain disease. I specifically focus on differential treatment or subgroup effects to investigate whether treatment may be more beneficial to some individuals (e.g. females) than other (e.g. males). 
Additional projects with METRICS include systematic reviews that focus on subgroup analyses, industry involvement, and redundancy/overlap.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow

company.name: Dutch Consortium for Healthcare Evaluation and Research in Obstetrics and Gynaecology

profile_positions.location: Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care, UMC Utrecht
profile_positions.company: Dutch Consortium for Healthcare Evaluation and Research in Obstetrics and Gynaecology
profile_positions.description: From 2009-2016 I served as a methodologist/epidemiologist/statistical consultant in the Dutch Consortium for Healthcare Evaluation and Research in Obstetrics and Gynaecology (www.studies-obsgyn.nl). I assisted principal investigators with methodological and statistical issues relating to their randomized clinical trials (7 published, 5+ ongoing) and supervised secondary analyses including prediction modelling studies and systematic reviews and individual participant data (network) meta-analysis, which up to date resulted in 20+ co-authorships including ones in major impact peer reviewed clinical journals such as Lancet (2), JAMA, and Obstetrics & Gynecology.
profile_positions.title: Methodologist/Epidemologist/Statistical Consultant

profile_positions.description: The Netherlands Perinatal Registry is a nationwide registry that contains data on pregnant women and their children (e.g. birthweight). Researchers/Clinicians can request to extract certain aggregate data from this registry (e.g. number of births in a certain hospital within a certain time frame). As employee data management I processed these requests. Statistical software used was mainly SAS, but SPSS and R were also used.
profile_positions.title: employee data management

profile_positions.location: Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, The Netherlands
profile_positions.description: In a collaboration between the Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, The Netherlands (Prof. E.W. Steyerberg, Dr. Y. Vergouwe) and the Netherlands Perinatal Registry (Dr. C.W. Hukkelhoven) I validated a prognostic model that aims to predict perinatal and neonatal death based on certain birth characteristics. The model was developed in England and we were interested in whether the model would perform equally well in a Dutch setting. The scientific paper of this internship was ultimately published in the best journal in the field of Pediatrics and later on published as an invited double publication in the Nederlands Tijdschrift voor Geneeskunde. Reference: Schuit E, Hukkelhoven CW, Manktelow BN, Papatsonis DN, de Kleine MJ, Draper ES, et al. Prognostic models for stillbirth and neonatal death in very preterm birth: a validation study. Pediatrics 2012 Jan;129(1):e120-e127 (Also an invited double publication in the Ned Tijdschr Geneeskd, see National journals).
profile_positions.title: trainee medical decision making
